ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I enjoyed getting to hear about all the other linguistics majors' projects.
How to identify a research topic and develop a research plan in the field of Linguistics.
How to write a final paper!
I learned more about how to do linguistics research. the main thing I learned about in this course was the work my peers are doing
This course helps you develop skills in conducting a large linguistics research project

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: Encourages independent work, flexible schedule, student presentations, collaboration
No weaknesses I could think of. All the strengths lie with the instructor, Dr. Zanuttini.

This class was very helpful in the sense that it helped me get work on my thesis and other projects done more quickly than they might have been if I had less structure around them. On the negative side of things, I often felt stressed by this class because I was being graded on work that is not usually assessed for a letter grade

I thought the main strength of Research Methods was getting us to put in effort toward our senior thesis, and I think this should be the main aim of the course -- getting good work done on the senior thesis. With that in mind, the main way to improve this course is to streamline things. I think the best way to do this would be to start the thesis work from the very beginning. It's nice to have some time to look at other senior theses, and think about how to introduce our subfield, but I feel like everyone taking the course knows that sooner or later they'll have to choose a senior thesis topic and begin research -- which means the sooner there is a deadline in the course to choose this topic and start reading background literature, the sooner everyone will begin work on their thesis, and then afterward everyone will have more time to focus on this topic, meet with an advisor, revise the topic, and research. I think another improvement that could be made is to decrease the amount of presentation done at the beginning of the course, e.g. presenting on the assignment to read prior senior essays and the assignment to introduce our subfield. This time would be better devoted to choosing a research topic earlier and presenting on your progress later in the semester. I think a presentation on your progress should be required later in the semester, but perhaps as a "everyone should do this at least once, but at any point, and it can be as informal as you wish" requirement to give everyone the flexibility to choose when they'll be best prepared to present. Another strength was the work we put in on writing fellowship essays, statements of purpose, etc.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, all in all it's an interesting time, and it's fun to learn about everyone else's work.
This is a core requirement of the linguistics major.
Yes! As a Linguistics student, it is required to graduate. But it is also helpful for those who want to write a research paper.
It is required for the major, but I do think the course is an excellent introduction to the senior thesis and also helps you work on some other professional goals. I found it very useful.
